title: Milei
text:
The Context
Explaining Milei’s rise to power

title: Milei
text:
The Context

2001: The Argentine Great Depression
What did the median voter learn from the 2001 crisis?

Neo-liberal reforms do not work
Free market policies are highly corrupt
Economic growth takes place at the expense of the poor
International organizations and financial institutinos are bad actors
The goverment must “do something”

Perfect setting the for the rise of a new left-leaning populist regime

title: Nicolas Cachanosky Director | Center for Free Enterprise   The University of Texas at El Paso
text:
CV
  
  
    
     
  
  
    
     
  
  
    
     
  

  
  


I’m an Associate Professor of Economics and the Director of the Center for Free Enterprise at The University of Texas at El Paso. I’m also a Senior Fellow at the American Institute for Economic Research nd a Fellow at the UCEMA Friedman-Hayek Center for the Study of a Free Society.
Along with João P. Bastos, I’m the editor of Public Choice in Latin America. I also serve as an Associate Editor of the Southern Economic Journal. Previously, I was president of the Association of Private Enterprise Education (APEE) and a director of The Mont Pelerin Society (MPS).
This website shares information about my research, and I regularly blog at Economic Order about economic policy and research.

title: Nicolas Cachanosky Director | Center for Free Enterprise   The University of Texas at El Paso
text:
I’m an Associate Professor of Economics and the Director of the Center for Free Enterprise at The University of Texas at El Paso. I’m also a Senior Fellow at the American Institute for Economic Research nd a Fellow at the UCEMA Friedman-Hayek Center for the Study of a Free Society.
Along with João P. Bastos, I’m the editor of Public Choice in Latin America. I also serve as an Associate Editor of the Southern Economic Journal. Previously, I was president of the Association of Private Enterprise Education (APEE) and a director of The Mont Pelerin Society (MPS).
This website shares information about my research, and I regularly blog at Economic Order about economic policy and research.
